instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00291: What is 820-00291? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with sensor issues
threads.message:
Hi guys,

I do not do iMacs (not very often at least) but this one belongs to a really nice customer and want to give it a try.

High fan speed and the photo is from the temp sensors... I checked for missing thermal sensors (like <TRANSISTOR>Q5670</TRANSISTOR> etc) but they are all there.. could it be <CHIP>U5650</CHIP>?

Thanks everyone.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with sensor issues
threads.message:
Both <CHIP>U5600</CHIP>/50 are placed in the same I2C bus.
So many temperature errors, related with both chips can't be caused by a sensor fail.
Something blocks correct communication on that bus.

Just in case, test disconnecting webcam.

Any history available?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with sensor issues
threads.message: Wil try that. The iMac was opened for some upgrade by the customer and this happened upon re-assembling it.
